newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft acquires some Macintosh technology.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft acquires some Macintosh technology.

text.p: Microsoft Corp said Wednesday it has acquired two Internet technologies that will be included in future versions of its Internet Explorer browser for Apple Computer Inc's Macintosh platform.
Microsoft said plans to incorporate the technologies in ResNova Software Inc's WebForOne and Boulevard products into future browser versions.
Microsoft also said it hired five members of the ResNova development team, who will work out of Microsoft's San Jose, Calif., offices. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

Microsoft said it will take WebForOne, which currently sells for about $39 at retail, and make it available free over the Internet under the name Personal Web Server for Macintosh. A beta version will be available by the end of the year.
The product, which will become part of Internet Explorer, allows small businesses, non-profit organizations and individuals to manage documents on internal networks or small Internet sites.
Microsoft already offers a similar product for its Windows 95 operating system.
